facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 395 of 1965 before the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal No. 395 of 1965. Appeal by special leave from the judgment

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated September 18, 1963 of the Calcutta High Court in Matter No. 97 of 1963.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated September 18, 1963 of the Calcutta High Court in Matter No. 97 of 1963.

facts.text: Calcutta High Court dismissed application under S. 33 of the Arbitration Act by judgment dated September 18, 1963.

anchor.surface_text: from the judgment of the Calcutta High Court dated September 18, 1963 dismissing an application under S. 33 of the Arbitra- tion Act.

facts.text: Appellant made offer for sale to respondent of 500 Bales 1,50,000 bags B Twills by letter dated September 14, 1960.

anchor.surface_text: By its letter dated September 14, 1960, the appellant made an offer for sale to the respondent of 500 Bales  1,50,000 bags  B Twills on the terms and companyditions mentioned in the said letter.

facts.text: Offer accepted by Director-General, Supplies Disposals on behalf of respondent by letter dated September 16, 1960.

anchor.surface_text: The offer was accepted by the Director- General, Supplies Disposals on behalf of the respondent by his letter No. CAL DL-1/5750-L II Modi/158 dated September 16, 1960.

facts.text: Appellant deposited Rs. 20,182-50 P. with Reserve Bank of India towards security deposit on September 22, 1960.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant deposited with the Reserve Bank of India the sum of Rs. 20,182-50 P. towards security deposit on September 22, 1960 as required by the acceptance letter.

facts.text: Date of delivery fixed under the contract was November 30, 1960.

anchor.surface_text: The date of delivery fixed under the companytract was November 30, 1960 and the respondent sent the appellant despatch instructions dated November 21, 1960,

facts.text: Respondent sent despatch instructions dated November 21, 1960 to appellant through Director of Supplies Disposals.

anchor.surface_text: the respondent sent the appellant despatch instructions dated November 21, 1960, through the Director of Supplies Disposals.

facts.text: On November 30, 1960, appellant intimated to respondent that the contract was void and illegal and requested refund of security deposit.

anchor.surface_text: On November 30, 1960 the appellant, however, intimated to the respondent that the companytract was void and illegal and requested that the security deposit should be refunded.

facts.text: Appellant claimed the contract violated Forward Contracts Regulation Act, 1952.

anchor.surface_text: The case of the appellant was that the companytract was in violation of the provisions of the Forward Contract  Regulation  Act, 1952  Act 74 of 1952 , hereinafter called the Act.

facts.text: Respondent stated contract legal and binding, appellant failed to deliver, would purchase goods at appellant's risk by letter dated December 1, 1960.

anchor.surface_text: By his letter dated December 1, 1960 the Director of Supplies wrote on behalf of the respondent that the companytract was legal and binding and as the appellant had failed to deliver the goods as provided in the agreement the respondent would purchase the goods at the risk of the appellant.

facts.text: Respondent incurred extra expenditure of about Rs. 76,410 and after crediting security deposit, Rs. 56,000 remained due from appellant.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent incurred extra expenditure amounting to about Rs. 76,410 and after giving credit to the appellant for the amount of Security Deposit, a sum of Rs. 56,000 still remained due to be paid by the appellant to the respondent.

facts.text: Respondent invoked arbitration clause 21 and appointed arbitrator.

anchor.surface_text: As the appellant failed to pay, the respondent took recourse to the arbitration cl. 21 of the companytract and appointed an Arbitra- tor to determine the dispute between the parties regarding the agreement.

facts.text: Appellant filed application under S. 33 of Arbitration Act before High Court for declaration that arbitration clause illegal and injunction against arbitration.

anchor.surface_text: Before the Arbitrator companyld give his award, the appellant filed an application before the High Court under S. 33 of the Arbitration Act praying for a declaration that the arbitration clause was illegal and void and for an injunction restraining the respondent from prosecuting the arbitration proceedings.

facts.text: Calcutta High Court by judgment dated November 19, 1963 held contract was non-transferable specific delivery contract not hit by the Act and dismissed application.

anchor.surface_text: By its judgment dated November 19, 1963, the High Court held that the companytract was a number-transferable specific delivery companytract and was number hit by the provisions of the Act and accordingly dismissed the application of the appellant.

facts.text: Central Government issued notification on March 29, 1958 under s.15(1) declaring section applicable to Jute goods in City of Calcutta etc.

anchor.surface_text: Such a numberification was issued,in this case by the Central Government on March 29, 1958 which is to the following effect In exercise of the powers companyferred by sub- section  1  of section 15 of the Forward Contracts  Regulation  Act, 1952  74 of 1952  the Central Government hereby declares that the said Section shall apply to Jute goods  Hessian cloth made of jute or bags made of such Hessian cloth and sacking cloth made of jute or bags made of such Sacking cloth  in the City of Calcutta.

facts.text: Supreme Court held the contract was non-transferable specific delivery contract within s.2(f) of the Act, not hit by notification.

anchor.surface_text: For the reasons already given, we hold that on a proper companystruction of the terms of the companytract and having regard to the surrounding circumstances there was an implied agreement between the parties that the rights and liabilities under the companytract were number to be transferred and the Bill of Lading relating to the companytract was also number to be transferred.

facts.text: Supreme Court dismissed the appeal confirming High Court decision.

anchor.surface_text: For the reasons expressed we hold that the decision of the Calcutta High Court dated September 18, 1963 is companyrect and this appeal must be dismissed with companyts.

facts.text: Contract governed by Form D.G.S. & D. 68 conditions, condition 10 with para 3(b) prohibiting subletting or assignment without permission.

anchor.surface_text: In the present case, it should be numbericed that the companytract cannot be sublet or assigned by the seller under companydition 10 read with para 3 b  of the Conditions of Contract companytained in Form D.G.S. D. 68 governing companytracts placed by the Central Purchase Organisation of the Government of India, 1959 edition.

facts.text: Jute bags intended for packing foodgrains arriving at Indian port, urgently required at Visakhapatnam Port.

anchor.surface_text: So far as the buyer is companycerned, the companytract itself shows that the jute bags were intended for packing foodgrains which were arriving in bulk at an Indian port. The last paragraph of the letter of acceptance dated September 16, 1960 states that the gunnies are very urgently required at the destination for packing imported foodgrains which are arriving in bulk

The question as to whether the contract was a transferable or non- transferable specific delivery contract is a question which ultimately depends on a reasonable construction of the contract. On behalf of the appellant it was pointed out that there was no specific clause in the contract which prohibited the transfer of the rights and liabilities or which prohibited transfer of the bill of lading. But the absence of such a specific clause is not conclusive as to the intention of the parties.

concepts.interpretation: Terms can be implied from expressed words and surrounding circumstances; absence of express prohibition not conclusive; legitimate to consider matrix of facts including contract conditions and purpose

arguments.claim: The contract was a forward contract prohibited by the government notification under the Act such that no rights or liabilities accrued and arbitration clause is ineffective

anchor.surface_text: It was argued on behalf of the appellant that the contract in question was a forward contract within the meaning of the Act and was prohibited by the Government notification and therefore no right or liability accrued to the parties on the basis of the contract. The contention of the appellant was that the contract was not a non-transferable specific delivery contract as defined in s. 2 (f) of the Act and as such it was illegal and void and the arbitration clause contained therein was of no effect and could not be availed of by either of the parties.

arguments.claim: Whether the contract is transferable or non-transferable specific delivery contract depends on reasonable construction of the contract taking surrounding circumstances into account

anchor.surface_text: The question as to whether the contract was a transferable or non- transferable specific delivery contract is a question which ultimately depends on a reasonable construction of the contract.

arguments.claim: Absence of specific clause prohibiting transfer is not conclusive on intention; terms can be implied; legitimate to consider surrounding circumstances

anchor.surface_text: But the absence of such a specific clause is not conclusive as to the intention of the parties. It is true that when a contract is reduced to writing we must look only to that writing. for ascertaining the terms of the agreement between the parties but it does not follow from this that it is only what is set out expressly and in so many words in the document that can constitute a term of the contract between the parties.

arguments.claim: Precedent in Khardah Company Ltd. v. Raymon & Co. holds absence of specific prohibition not conclusive on non-transferability

anchor.surface_text: As was pointed out by this Court in Khardah Company Ltd. v. Raymon Co. India Private Ltd., the absence of a specific clause prohibiting transfer is not conclusive one way or the other on the question whether there was an agreement between the parties that the contract was to be non-transferable.

arguments.claim: Contract prohibits subletting or assignment by seller under condition 10 para 3(b) of Form D.G.S. & D. 68

anchor.surface_text: In the present case, it should be noticed that the contract cannot be sublet or assigned by the seller under condition 10 read with para 3 (b) of the Conditions of Contract contained in Form D.G.S. & D. 68 governing contracts placed by the Central Purchase Organisation of the Government of India, 1959 edition.

arguments.claim: Contract terms and circumstances show jute bags urgently required for specific packing at Visakhapatnam port with named consignee and inspection, implying non-transferability

anchor.surface_text: So far as the buyer is concerned, the contract itself shows that the jute bags were intended for packing foodgrains which were arriving in bulk at an Indian port. The last paragraph of the letter of acceptance dated September 16, 1960 states that the gunnies are very urgently required at the destination for packing imported foodgrains which are arriving in bulk

arguments.claim: Bill of Lading normally negotiable but parties contemplated non-transfer of rights/liabilities and Bill of Lading

anchor.surface_text: It was pointed out for the appellant that normally the Bill of Lading partakes of the nature of a negotiable instrument and by endorsing it the holder of the bill of Lading can transfer the property in the goods to which the Bill of Lading relates

arguments.claim: Contract is non-transferable specific delivery contract under s.2(f) not hit by s.15(1) notification

anchor.surface_text: For the reasons already given, we hold that on a proper construction of the terms of the contract and having regard to the surrounding circumstances there was an implied agreement between the parties that the rights and liabilities under the contract were not to be transferred and the Bill of Lading relating to the contract was also not to be transferred.

holdings.text: on a proper construction of the terms of the contract and having regard to the surrounding circumstances there was an implied agreement between the parties that the rights and liabilities under the contract were not to be transferred and the Bill of Lading relating to the contract was also not to be transferred

anchor.surface_text: For the reasons already given, we hold that on a proper construction of the terms of the contract and having regard to the surrounding circumstances there was an implied agreement between the parties that the rights and liabilities under the contract were not to be transferred and the Bill of Lading relating to the contract was also not to be transferred.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Reasonable construction of contract terms, prohibition on assignment, urgency of purpose, named consignee, inspection requirements, and surrounding circumstances imply non-transferability

holdings.text: the contract in question was a non-transferable specific delivery contract within the meaning of s. 2(f) of the Act and the contract was not hit by the notification dated March 29, 1958 issued by the Central Government under s. 15(1) of the Act

anchor.surface_text: It follows therefore that the contract in question was a non-transferable specific delivery contract within the meaning of s. 2 f  of the Act and the contract was not hit by the notification dated March 29, 1958 issued by the Central Government under s. 15 1  of the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Implied non-transferability satisfies definition under s.2(f); exempted from prohibitions under ss.15,17 by s.18

holdings.text: the decision of the Calcutta High Court dated September 18, 1963 is correct and this appeal must be dismissed with costs

anchor.surface_text: For the reasons expressed we hold that the decision of the Calcutta High Court dated September 18, 1963 is correct and this appeal must be dismissed with costs.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Contract valid and non-transferable specific delivery not prohibited by Act, so s.33 application rightly dismissed

holdings.text: the absence of a specific clause prohibiting transfer is not conclusive one way or the other on the question whether there was an agreement between the parties that the contract was to be non-transferable

anchor.surface_text: As was pointed out by this Court in Khardah Company Ltd. v. Raymon Co. India Private Ltd., the absence of a specific clause prohibiting transfer is not conclusive one way or the other on the question whether there was an agreement between the parties that the, contract was to be non-transferable.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Terms may be implied from expressed words, whole document, and legitimate surrounding circumstances; follows precedent

holdings.text: it was not contemplated by the parties that the rights under the contract should be transferred either by the buyers or by the sellers

anchor.surface_text: In view of all these circumstances we are of opinion that it was not contemplated by the parties that the rights under the contract should be transferred either by the buyers or by the sellers.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Contract conditions prohibit subletting/assignment, specific urgent purpose for foodgrains packing, inspection, named consignee indicate personal performance

outcome.relief_summary: Appeal dismissed with costs; Calcutta High Court decision dated September 18, 1963 upheld as correct; contract held non-transferable specific delivery contract not prohibited by the Act.

anchor.surface_text: As was pointed out by this Court in Khardah Company Ltd. v. Raymon Co. India Private Ltd., the absence of a specific clause prohibiting transfer is not conclusive one way or the other on the question whether there was an agreement between the parties that the, contract was to be non-transferable.
For the reasons expressed we hold that the decision of the Calcutta High Court dated September 18, 1963 is correct and this appeal must be dismissed with costs.
